title: Tim Chen
text:
I am an Honours Bachelor of Science (HBSc) student at the University of Toronto, specializing in Mathematics and its Applications (Probability & Statistics) with minors in Computer Science and Statistics. I am passionate about using data-driven methods to solve real-world problems, particularly through statistical analysis, machine learning, and data visualization.
In my academic journey, I have completed relevant coursework in Machine Learning (Python), Statistical Theory, Databases (SQL), and Software Design (Java), among others.
I have professional experience as a Frontend Software Engineer Intern at MAYOHR, where I enhanced customer service efficiency and streamlined backend integration using Python and JavaScript. Additionally, I served as an Events Executive for ROCSAUT, coordinating large-scale events and reducing costs through effective budgeting and data analysis.
I am skilled in a variety of programming languages, including Python, R, SQL, Java, and C, as well as tools like Tableau, Power BI, and Excel. My certifications include the Google Data Analytics Professional Certificate, showcasing expertise in data cleaning, visualization, and statistical analysis.


Selected Projects

Examining Violent Crime in Toronto

Performed Bayesian logistic regression in R to identify significant predictors.

Explore the project



Traffic Collision Analysis in Toronto

Created an interactive Tableau dashboard to visualize trends and hotspots.

Explore the project



Predicting Diabetes Risk Factors

Used logistic regression in R to predict and analyze key diabetes indicators.

Explore the project



Housing Price Prediction

Conducted multiple linear regression in R to predict housing prices based on various features.

Explore the project





Professional Experience

Frontend Software Engineer Intern, MAYOHR

Built and maintained a high-traffic website using JavaScript, HTML, and CSS, enabling a 30% faster resolution time for customer service inquiries.

Reduced integration bottlenecks by 25% through Python-based frontend testing before backend implementation.

Collaborated with product managers to design features that increased troubleshooting efficiency by 40%.

University of Toronto
